Situation1: They conduct an in-depth consultation with a patient taking multiple high-risk medications to prevent dangerous interactions.
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today, and I am the leader of the session.
Story: The clock on the pharmacy wall ticked closer to six, the time I was supposed to lead our weekly meditation group. I glanced at the patient in front of me, an elderly woman with a bag full of prescriptions—blood thinners, diabetes meds, a new heart pill. She looked anxious, clutching her list of questions. As a pharmacist, I knew I couldn’t rush this. She needed careful counseling to avoid dangerous interactions, and I was the only one here with the expertise. But as a Buddhist, I was expected to be present for my sangha, to guide them in mindfulness and stillness. They relied on me to open the session, to set the tone for our practice. My mind tugged in two directions: the duty to my patient’s safety, and the commitment to my spiritual community. I felt my breath quicken, the irony not lost on me—a mindfulness teacher, now anything but mindful, caught between two worlds, both demanding my full attention.
